awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports research on the mathematical side of the interaction between theoretical particle physics and mathematics. This interaction started with the advent of string theory in the 1980's and has become a huge source of inspiration in mathematics, often connecting hitherto disconnected areas of research. The Donaldson-Thomas invariants under investigation in this project are a mathematical version of the count of certain D-branes, which are higher-dimensional objects in string theory providing boundary conditions for open strings. The importance of such counts comes from the multitude of relations to other mathematical objects and notions, such as quiver representations, instantons, stability conditions, and Gromov-Witten invariants. Donaldson-Thomas-type invariants are also central to a long list of questions and conjectures posed both by physicists and mathematicians.

This project will develop and test a theory of a logarithmic framework for Donaldson-Thomas invariants. The logarithmic version is designed for treating situations relative to a divisor and for studying degenerating families. This extension is of importance for the interpretation of the invariants, for computations, for new applications, and as a proof-theoretic tool, thus greatly expanding the scope of Donaldson-Thomas theory.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
A fundamental technique in geometry is the study of degenerate limits of families of geometric objects. A classical example is a family of hyperbolas in the plane degenerating to the union of coordinate axes. In classical algebraic geometry there is a master parameter space, the Hilbert scheme, parametrizing all subsets of projective space that are the simultaneous zero set of polynomial equations such as the hyperbola, or the intersection of a hyperbolic cone with a plane. Novel ("virtual") techniques of intersection theory on Hilbert schemes have been used to construct the Donaldson-Thomas invariants in the title of the project.

Logarithmic geometry is a version of algebraic geometry adapted to a particularly controllable class of degeneration situations. A theory of logarithmic Donaldson-Thomas invariants, a major aim of this research, has been developed in competing work of Maulik and Ranganathan at the end of the first year of the grant. The focus of the work then shifted to develop basic technology (1) for the handling of the underlying moduli spaces of logarithmic objects, and (2) for the generalization of the theory to higher dimensional objects with the aim to develop a fundamental new tool in algebraic geometry.

For (1) major progress was achieved in the thesis of Yixian Wu in a closely related context that emphasized the importance of understanding the polyhedral geometry underlying logarithmic degeneration situations. This progress in particular lead to a deep understanding of the intrinsic construction of mirror pairs, pairs of different spaces that lead to dual string theories.

A major insight concerning (2) is that the beautiful theory of one-dimensional objects in logarithmic geometry is really special to one dimensions. For a similar treatment in higher dimensions, serious compromises have to be made. This limits the usefulness and interest in the logarithmic version of the Hilbert scheme. Progress has also been made on the understanding of quantum corrections in local Calabi-Yau geometries.

Research related to this grant involved 4 PhD students and two postdocs. With its interdisciplinary nature, it has provided excellent training for the academic workforce.
